results.title: The Color of paradise = The Colour of paradise
results.creator_credit: Varahonar Film Company, Mehdi Karimi and Majid Majidi
results.brief_description: After the end of term at a school for the blind in Teheran, Mohammed, an eight year old blind boy, and his father make the long journey on foot and horseback back to their village in the northern highlands of Iran. Though Mohammed quickly settles back into his idyllic life in the country with his two sisters and his grandmother, his widower father, who wants to remarry, decides to send him to work for a blind carpenter far from home. The film starts with a child’s perception of the world and expands its vision to encompass the emotional complexities of the adult world. Dividing the focus evenly between Mohammed and his father, it provides insight into wider social and cultural issues at play which resonate deeply through the caustic comments of the boy’s grandmother. While the soundtrack’s constantly shifting chorus of birds, insects, wind and rain draws attention to the sounds Mohammad hears, the film also reveals the beauty he is unable to see. Moving through fields of flowers and misty forests, across streams and into the craggy backwoods country, it offers a visionary experience of the natural world. Cast includes Hossein Mahjoub, Mohsen Ramezani, Salime Feizi and Farahnaz Safari. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: The Color of man
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Robert Carl Cohen
results.brief_description: Explains the reason for variation in skin color of people of the different nationalities. The film describes how in prehistoric times humans living near the equator could not protect themselves from the direct ultra-violent rays of the sun, and did not survive unless they developed a protective pigment in their skin known as melanin. Similarly those living away from the direct ultra-violet developed a fair skin which permitted the rays to penetrate, for a certain amount of ultra-violet light is essential for life. Narrated by Robert Doubleday.

results.title: The Colonies and Britain
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit and Colonial Office
results.brief_description: Shows the part played by Britain in making her colonies, particularly those in Africa, technically and economically ready for self-government. Illustrates how the Colonial Office is taking measures in Africa to fight disease, plague and ignorance, how the valuable resources of the colonies are being surveyed and how the necessary technical equipment is being supplied to develop these resources for the benefit of the peoples of the area.

results.title: The Colonial chair
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Patricia Ludford
results.brief_description: Two men are each determined to purchase a colonial chair on sale at Sydney’s Salvation Army’s Collection and Waste Products Depot. After a short argument the victor carries off the chair on his motorbike. Filmed on several Saturday mornings, we see bargain hunters assembled outside the gates until 7.30 a.m. opening time. As the gates open there is a rush for the choicest lots in stoves, refrigerators, furniture and bric-a-brac. Photography: Ron Lowe

results.title: The Colonel comes to Japan
results.brief_description: Provides a fascinating look at the highly successful marketing of the Kentucky Fried Chicken product in Japan, noting the modifications to the standard American approach adopted to suit the Japanese business philosophy and life style. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The Colombo Plan
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and Joy Batchelor
results.brief_description: A cartoon film on the Colombo Plan which links a number of countries throughout the world pledged to improve each other’s economic conditions. To increase prosperity and make the earth fruitful, technical knowledge and experience, equipment and funds, are essential before progress can be made. This cartoon shows how, in the past ten years, the people of Colombo Plan countries are benefitting from co-operation.

results.title: The Cologne sports college
results.brief_description: The Sports College in Cologne was founded in 1947. Its aim is to train sports teachers for schools and coaches for sports clubs. The Sports College in Cologne founded in 1947 gives instruction in all branches of sport, theory and practice, to teachers from primary and secondary schools, future physical education industries, youth leaders, local and overseas students. The college has a well-equipped research laboratory to study respiration and circulation during physical exertion and research into muscular fatigue. Coaches include ex-Olympic championing instructing students in athletic, weight training, swimming, gymnastics, javelin throwing.

results.title: The Colditz story
results.creator_credit: British Lion Films, Ivan Foxwell and Guy Hamilton
results.brief_description: The Germans believed that no man could escape form Colditz Castle, set as it was in the heart of the Reich, 400 miles from any neutral frontier. This film tells the story of how the British, French, Dutch and Polish prisoners of war who were incarcerated in Colditz set out to prove their captors wrong. Starring John Mills and Eric Portman. Based on the novel “The Colditz story” by P.R. Reid.

results.title: The Coen brothers
results.brief_description: This low-key documentary on filmmaking brothers Ethan and Joel Coen, was made during the filming of “O Brother where art thou?” The media shy brothers are reputed for playing with established film genres, and a disciplined approach that has enabled them to gain autonomy from studio executives and artistic freedom to create idiosyncratic, original work. Their oeuvre includes “Fargo”, “Raising Arizona”, “The Big Lebowski”, “The Hudsucker proxy”, “Miller’s crossing” and “Barton Fink”. The Coens’ meticulous planning of production allows them to consistently deliver films on budget that often achieve cult status. As a film student Joel was working on others’ low budget films, before undertaking the writing of original scripts with his philosophy graduate brother, Ethan. Their first film, “Blood simple” was an instantaneous alternative classic. The brothers have an unusual style in that they both contribute to filmmaking tasks and share screenwriting recognition, but Joel is credited with directing and Ethan with producing. Features interviews with the Coens, George Clooney, Peter Stormare, Holly Hunter, Jeff Bridges, John Turturro, former school teachers, and a range of close friends who attempt to explain the Coens’ relaxed and symbiotic working relationship. Although they have made the occasional dud, the Coens are consistent in their output and appear to have an untapped well of ideas at their disposal.
